body:
*EDIT* 
Based on 
https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/ms633548(v=vs.85).aspx

We should use `SW_SHOWNA` which is the "no activation" variant of `SW_SHOW`
`SW_SHOWNOACTIVATE` is the "no activation" variant of `SW_SHOWNORMAL`.
I have edited my text above + pushed a new branch that the incoming PR will use.

issue.title: Win32: Fix _glfwPlatformShowWindow() from activating the window

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Bug reports and bugfix pull requests

repository.name: glfw
repository.description: A multi-platform library for OpenGL, OpenGL ES, Vulkan, window and input

body:
> `glfwShowWindow()` always calls `_glfwPlatformShowWindow` + `_glfwPlatformFocusWindow`, which seems redundant with the the fact that `glfwFocusWindow()` exists.
> My intuition it that it would it be more correct and consistent to remove that call to `_glfwPlatformFocusWindow()` in `glfwShowWindow()`, however: that extra call was added in 89f438d "Fix window focus regression" (March 2016) so I imagine there is more to it.

Yeah, I find it weird that baf5744 first fixes the `glfwShowWindow` saying

> This removes the (undocumented) behavior where glfwShowWindow would
> bring the window to front and set input focus.  That function now
> does what it says.

And then 89f438d reverts that fix saying

> Regression caused by baf5744.

My suspicion is that the casual user would expect glfwShowWindow() to set make the window "ready" and therefore the focus, so it is partly a documentation problem + partly a backward compatibility problem.

Luckily it would only affect a subset of users (those who set GLFW_VISIBLE to fals?), and the behavioral change would be fairly easy to spot and change as well.
Edit: confused `GLFW_VISIBLE` with `GLFW_FOCUSED` in my comment, so removing it.

> We should use `SW_SHOWNA` which is the "no activation" variant of `SW_SHOW`

Yup. That was an oversight in baf574494da1f1b6a07ff426c62670090e67b445. Thank you!

> Now honestly, I am confused about the exact meaning of "activation" in the Win32 api but essentially it looks like we are losing the focus

Correct. They're essentially the same for us as we don't have child windows. Here is [the official explanation of active window](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/ms632599(v=vs.85).aspx#active).

> My suspicion is that the casual user would expect glfwShowWindow() to set make the window "ready" and therefore the focus, so it is partly a documentation problem + partly a backward compatibility problem.

Yep, that's it exactly and I was quite sensibly asked to revert, so we're somewhat stuck with the current behavior until 4.0.
This has been fixed with 20b12204af481d863e9a256f973e2bf7dc480c53 by @ocornut.
@elmindreda Should I create a ticket for the `glfwShowWindow` issue for GLFW 4.0?
@ghuser404 It might be good to have an issue people can find for it. I added it to [the list](https://github.com/glfw/glfw/wiki/GLFW-4.0-sketchbook) for now.
Just for the records, for the (B) part of this I _think_ I can find a workaround for my specific use case.
Inclusion into GLFW 4.0 sketchbook sounds good enough to me.
@ocornut If it turns out you can't, we can add a function that only calls `_glfwPlatformShowWindow`.
